												As a causal driver not a big racing game fan, the Crew suits me well.The game engine seems not advanced, even a little bit outdated at your first look, but I'm just in love with this good old classic atmosphere, because the view, the building, the land describing are actually realistic. Beside, the CREW dev TEAM have made a big improvement on this game after the wild run and the call all units pack, the game's view is really getting better and better like the lighting, now there are huge differences compares to the original release version, which really seems dark and dull, but now I feel like it could catch up with the Horizon 3, which I don't feel like to play anymore, because the CREW has better atmosphere for casual drive.I really recommend you guys try to run it in 1440P,32 inch screen, you will feel much MUCH immersed and much detailed than in 1080P. For 1440P you just need a RX480 4G and a desktop i5 CPU, you will get 60fps at high settings most of the time. If have connecting issue, a VPN is recommended.This game is quite unique, you cant find any other game that cover the whole america. I could drive or wonder as far as I like, just to see the view, feeling relaxed. Once I all most cry in the the snow-covered mountain land cause the view is so breath-taking. At last I really hope Ubisoft can make a Chinese Version like those newly released Ubisoft games, excellent game like this should be known and enjoyed by more people.

content:
29, 2014
												The Crew is everything I have hoped for in a racing game for years. It combines the fantastic customization options of Need For Speed: Underground with the thrill of the high speed chases of Hot Pursuit, as well as including more serious racing environments for fans of series like Forza and Gran Turismo, and even putting heavy focus on rallycross and extreme offroad racing.The storyline (at least as much of it that was included in the beta) was interesting the whole way through, even if it seemed like it was lacking in dialogue every now and then. The Crew offers a break away from the typical racing game storylines while still keeping you in the spirit of racing the whole time. The open world is enormous and has a lot of exploration and events to offer. The beta version included only the United States map, and I only had time to explore from Chicago to the east (and not even all of the east!). I don't know how much of the rest of the world will be included in the full release, but I am eager to find out come November. All in all, I give the game a SOLID 9/10. I'm nothing short of absolutely thrilled for the full release of the game, and would HIGHLY recommend it to anyone with remote interest in open world or racing games.

												This game has got a massive amount of negative reviews... and to be honest is the best racer i have ever played.I did get the Gold version on sale so am reviewing at about a $40 price tag.Pros:Enough content to keep you playing for life (Skills/PvP/Faction and Story Missions.)Graphics - Buttery smooth on my setupOpen World (US scaled by Autodesk)The satellite animations zooming from map view to car and vice versa is damn sexyUpgrading of cosmetics and performance for cars is prettySkill level upgrading - driver and performance parts upgrading for carsCons:Main problem I have is that at the moment servers are packed with players but if UPlay or the Crew servers are down, you cannot play until they are back up. Physics of 'barriers' on collision can have the strangest effects at times like space shuttle launch type strange :) First impression: Bought a Camarro... took it out on the street thinking it was going to be me and some ai doing missions. Came across these 3 Russian dudes doing donuts in a side street... They invited me to their Crew and we finished the Story missions together and are working on faction missions. There is no language barrier for burning rubber and nitrous fumes.Each has their own impression ... for me this is 11/10 and supercedes NFS and Grid series with drawing me in and return value to the game.

content:
, 2016
												I would say I absolutely do recommend this game if you like games like Test Drive Unlimited, and Need For Speed, that being said, there are some MAJOR downsides to this game but overall I find it a rather good game.Let's start with the cons to get that out of the way.   -Hard to Start OutAs in it's rather hard to get money for actual good vehicles. I feel as you progress more, it'll be easier but when you have to go and get performance vehicles.... be prepared to spend lots of your time grinding for money if you want an actual decent car.   -RankedI feel as though they let you go into ranked WAY too early as I went into it (Not at all knowing what I was doing...) and was matched with the top of the top players (Platinum, Gold, Etc.). While they had level 1499 Vehicles, i sat there with a puny level 300..... As that may be my own fault for rushing it, I just recommend if you play to wait a LONG time before playing ranked.   -Street ChallengesAs this may just be my own personal opinion, I find as you're driving down the road, the excessive amount of Street Challenges are way too much. They typically cover the entire road, and frankly try to force you to do them. You literally have to swerve off the side of the road to avoid them... Personally, I just find them annoying as they hardly reward you anything and are quite dull, typically trying to force me off the path I was originally going.    -Wild RunAs this isn't nessicarily a con to me, I find lots of people complaining since the season pass didnt include Wild Run. As I didn't pre-order or buy the Season Pass expecting it (Due to me buying the game far after the big fuss about it happened) I don't find this really a con since it's only $10 more. Though do be warned, season pass doesn't include ALL dlc like most games have it. It lacks a big item that the game basically requires and tries to force onto you, Wild Run.   -Basic Story PlotI won't spoil anything for you but, if you have ever played Need For Speed: Undercover.... This is basically that game. It has pratically the exact same plot and will give you extreme de ja vu.    -Bad Graphics...As this isn't such a big deal to me, the graphics for some things do make me laugh. The graphics for scratches are incredibly cheaply made... That's really all I have for that one... It's just rather funny how horrible they are. Now Onto the Pros  -Long StoryAt the time of writing this, I am 10.3 Hours into the game, and still not even halfway into the game. It seems to be VERY long which I absolutely love, something most games nowadays seem to lack.  -Some Nice CarsThere are some very nice, detailed cars in the game. Though expensive.   -EntertainingI've always been a big fan of Racing Games and I can say, this game I absolutely fell in love with. It's one game that I can actually sit down and play for a long while without getting bored, which is very few for me.     -ControlsOkay, This is moreso to personal preference but - The Controls for this game is rather different compared to most games. If you're using a controller, it may seem a bit weird just to how the handling is, but I can say after a while you will get use to it. I personally fell in love with it. I would probably rate this game 7/10... It could definitely be better, but It's still rather good. A nice relaxing game to come home to if you have nothing else to do

content:
er 7, 2014
												I'm sure most of you have already watched movies such as the Fast and Furious, right? Now, who wouldn't want to roleplay as a bunch of street racers out cruising on the city with pimped-out rides fighting for bragging rights?The Crew is an open world, online multiplayer arcade racing game that lets you crew up with people to challenge others all over five major areas in the United States. That single line alone got me hooked enough to take the game and see for myself. After several hours clocked in, I managed to pin-point a few things that make this game great, at the same time notice a few issues that could be resolved in the future hopefully.The Pros:- Probably one of the biggest selling points of this game is the fact that it's open world. They weren't kidding when they said, "If you can see it, you can drive there" part, with a minor exception from the world's boundaries. From busy streets, to wide highways, to rocky mountain tops, to the vast fields. You can race, or chill-out, practically anywhere given that you have already driven to that spot before. To add to this, the game allows you to warp anywhere with minimal to no loading time whatsoever. Always a plus on my book.- The rides aren't limited to your typical street racer tuning. The game has several specifications that works on certain terrain and objectives. It allows you to customize your ride to best suit the situation at hand, like dirt specs for off-road challenges, and raid specs for heavy duty pursuits. A large chunk of the pimping-out option is available as visual customization for your ride, allowing drivers to make unique rides that they can show-off to others, or look awesome winning in them during races.- This is a multiplayer game after all, so what could be more exciting than racing as a crew? Imagine cruising down the streets as a 4-man team out looking for trouble or a challenge. Visualize being chased down by cops while your crewmates dive right in to clear a path for you. Or you could just troll people around and block busy streets just for fun.The Cons:- No game is perfect after all, especially during its first launch, so don't expect too much or you'll just end up disappointed like some. While the game is labled as an MMO, players are divided into "sessions" much like RPG games have "server channels". Most of the time players see only a handful of people in their current session, sometimes no one at all. While I have no idea what are the maximum number of players per session is, it would be nice if I could see 20+ drivers or so in every coast. Not too much though, or it would be chaos. Some people are complaining about not being able to see their friends in-game as well to crew up, which is quite a let down.- AI in this game is quite annoying in my opinion. First of, the term "rubberbanding", in reference to the elasticity of a rubber band, means that car A will not move too far away from car B in most situations. For example, you're in a race wherein you're in first place. The 2nd place AI will "rubberband" its way towards you no matter what situation it gets stuck in. It will suddenly dive towards you at ridiculous speeds even if it had just recovered from a crash. It works both ways when you're the one at 2nd, the 1st place AI seems to slow down a bit to allow you to get back into the race. Imagine the "rubberbanding" on police vehicles, chases aren't as exciting as it should be. In fact, it's difficult and down right scary.- The physics and controls on this game is a little off, I think. I mean, yes, driving at high speeds have this tendency to lose control obviously. But the handling and recovery is just too darn difficult.  The vehicles tend to spin-out easily, lose traction and so on. Let's not get started on the police, especially when they decide to break in front of you, they turn into a solid brick wall you can't possibly push aside. On the plus side, however, these cops really know how to do pit manouvers and stuff. And I think the handling of the cars can be remedied with the right car parts. Just expect to have a hard time at the start though.All in all, despite the ups and downs, The Crew is still a fun game to have, especially if you love the challenge and the thought of having one awesome ride as an avatar. It's barely a week into release and I'm sure we can expect better things to come from this game. If you're debating on picking this up, my personal opinion is go for it.  I mean, why not? It's not a bad game, but it's not the best either, but I'm sure this game has potential to get up there on the list. Hope to see you guys on the streets. Later.

content:
er 3, 2014
												Find some people on Steam to play with and form a Crew. I have made 3 great new friends in the past 2 days from playing this game. Having people to play/cooperate/compete with makes this game so much fun, and you will always try to beat each-others records on trials and watch their tail during races. It is co-op, so if the objective is (for example that we found) to, say, finish 3rd or higher, and only one person in the event achieves it, you all get rewarded. I usually am the brute in our Crew, I drive a Dirt or Street spec'd Ford Raptor. I will keep the AI drivers at bay by ramming and cutting them off, and my friends will use their Skyline or Charger to win the race(Though the Raptor can perfectly keep up if I want!). We all have a role that we use to emerge victorious as a group, and the game really rewards teamwork.--There is so much I would like to write about, but I am tired (from playing so long). The driving isn't Asetto Corsa level, but if you want to have a blast driving, this game does it. I have had some times where the others went off line, and I just drove, and drove, and drove, and went to the coast, traveled to the mountains and hot-swapped for my Dirt-spec ride and tore up the ground all the way down the mountain.--If you have a steering wheel with force feedback, The Crew uses every ounce of it. I was a beta tester, and I was surprised that they had full support for my wheel, the Logitech Driving Force GT. It's not a mainstream wheel, it was designed for the PS3, but it works on PC with 900 degrees of rotation and force feedback. All the buttons work, I have not had to tweak anything. It just, WORKED.--Ask me anything you like in the comments, I would be happy to answer questions you have about the game.

15, 2015
												The Crew represents what I personally missed in recent racing games. It isn't a racing simulator, so don't expect full realism while in the driver' seat, but what you get in terms of handling is more than enough to enjoy the fun. Simply put: there's a fair background story, many cars, a gazillion of races and an explorable map that is the whole U.S.A. territory; all of this is what makes The Crew a very good arcade racing game. Sometimes, though, the arcade model becomes too evident (yes, Raid-spec "smuggling runs"... while also some PvP events...), but all in all this is an experience worth trying, especially if you plan to play it using a racing wheel set like the Logitech G27 (fully supported). If you're an old NFS fan and miss the good old Most Wanted times, here you'll find your new home.

content:
er 18, 2014
												I have been playing The Crew for about 2 hours.From a racing simulation point of view, the game lacks in various areas such as handling, physics, drivetrain, shifting. All vehicle handles nearly the same, with more or less understeer. Gearbox is odd, and slow while shifting/down shifting, handbraking is slow. On road, cars rarely spin out, but when pushing them to the limit, the cars will throw the rear end out, but refusing to turn. There are three modes of driving: All Assistance, Sport, Hardcore. All assistance would include ABS, Traction, steering stability, etc. Hardcore has less traction and less steering stability. Drifting is a pain in the ♥♥♥ on keyboard, but manageable on Sport and Hardcore mode.Tuning is simplified and a lot easier for the general audience, nothing too complicated. Parts are found during runs and story events, Gold, Silver, Bronze, each adding x amount of additional car level. Level cap for players is at 50. Level caps for cars are at 1299.From a car enthusiast point of view, for those who just wants to collect and drive the cars, and tune (not in-depth tuning), this game is great. Graphics are beautiful, damages to the vehicle is mildly realistic, environment is great. You wont be able to run over people though, just like that in Driver San Francisco, they would jump away with Level 9001 reflex skills. Engine sound effects on the cars come close to that of real cars, but only when not in cutscenes. Engine sounds from cutscenes souds like that of a muscle car, V6/V8. Collecters will still need to play the game and some events to make money, in order to mod the car. Game is Pay to Win or Play to Win.The R34 GT-R is left hand drive, which does not exist, and makes the petrolhead in me heartbroken.The Street Car upgrade in game gives a wheel (rim) which resembles 5Zigen Noir, which makes the Purist in me cry. Other recognizable brand of wheels (for those who care) includes: BBS (:D), HRE (:D), ROTA (D:), Volk Racing (:D) and of course, Original Equipment Manufacterer (OEM) wheels.All Street Cars are stock height, which makes me Iacrophobic.Game cannot be played with no internet connection, from what I've seen.Best part about the game is that they have a replica Pike's Peak Uphill/Downhill sprint run in the Midwest. Very fun to do a tandem drifting run up/down with a friend.Rate Game 6/10. It's not bad, but it's far from perfect. Definitely recommend for car lovers. Definitely a great game to go cruising around with friends and racing around town.

content:
ry 2, 2015
												I've clocked almost 50 hours in The Crew - an obvious recommendation. I am currently level 27 and still exploring the first of 5 regions (more about that later). Why is it fun?The Crew has a huge map, a huge number of difficult races and skill challenges, reasonable AI, the longest races I have ever seen in a computer game, a varied selection of cars right from the start, and a good system for levelling up cars, doing PvP, and doing co-op PvE with or without friends. It is a bit of a cross between FUEL (its game world is bigger, but emptier) and NFS:World (which has a more crowded MMO-feeling, but is pay2win and not as social). It has Burnout Paradise's ability to initiate challenges right in the game world without going to an instance, so you may be driving along and see a car flying through the air because you're passing a jump challenge and someone's doing it; or see everyone else's police pursuits (join in if you like).The level cap is at 50, there are 5 regions, you can go anywhere at any time, but the events and cars of a new region unlock every 10 levels. So in theory, since my main focus is still the first region (Mid-West - of course you start in Detroit), I shouldn't be over level 10, upgrading my car with level 1-10 parts won from skill challenges available in that region, and generally having a good time; and I should be able to level out of that region by following the storyline missions, if I like, which I probably am. But the game also provides other ways to level up: you can grind story missions (even accidentally, if you want to improve your score from bronze to gold; and the game also makes you, because other player will invite you on coop runs - of course you can decline), you can do faction missions once you are level 10 (out of curiosity), or you can do PvP (a dozen races was enough to get me from level 21 to 27). This will unlock other car types (good) and the parts sets that come with the level (bad, because I now could just buy me all level 20 parts for my car and skip the East Coast region altogether, and with a bit more PvP, skip the South, too). Maybe The Crew should have taken a slice from GuildWars, where you're a) PvP-ready from the beginning with competitive gear (but you can use your own high-end PvE gear as well), and b) levels and player capabilities are adjusted on the fly depending on the level of the region you're in so that co-op works well.Right now, I exercise some restraint and explore and do the skill challenges and the exploration anyway, and the nice thing about The Crew is that even though my cars are somewhat overpowered for the zone (what with the stat boost levelling up gives them -- why, exactly?), the challenges are still tough to get golden. At the rate I'm going, there'll be many more hours of fun in this game.If I could do it over, I would play each story mission only once and stay away from anything social (PvP, Factions, co-op) until level 40 at least. Recommended.

number of helpful: 23 of 39 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
er 11, 2014
												So...... you like to drive huh?Thats what this game has to offer. Its truly not some entirely new racing experience. Its midnight club, burnout, need for speed, all rolled into a new game, The Crew. Many people have criticized this game for its sub-par graphics, arcade like driving/physics, and it not being a true "MMO". And while that may be true in many cases, you also must take into account for the scale of this game. No other game truly allows you to drive from Miami to LA in one sitting all the while seeing every different biome along the way. It's fulfilling to be able to go from a small town, to the mountains, to main roads, and then to main cities. I will admit that this game is far from completely polished but that does not mean its fun and enjoyable. I have around 50 hours right now and while around 25 of that was the main story, the rest has been me farming the skill missions and overall, trying to explore the massive world of The Crew. So in the end, yes you might not be getting a perfect game, but its still one to remember, and it will continue to get better with patches, dlcs, etc etc.

content:
27, 2016
Must buy at any price [x]
Worth the money but wait for a small sale [✓]
Wait for a huge discount [x]
Avoid at all costs [x] INTRODUCTION The Crew, a game made by Ivory Tower which are former Test Drive developers, Test Drive was a good game loved by many so everyone had alot of high expectations for The Crew (very high expectations) which is why some people were disappointed, for over-hyping this.That doesn't mean The Crew is bad though, it's an open world (very open world with no invisible walls, except a huge wall beside Mexico) racing game, it has a story , official cars with a wide variety, replayability, but you may ask "Isn't it once you finish The Crew it's done?" yes it does, BUT , you can buy very low level cars and feel like it's a new run again. CARS I think we all had huge hopes for good cars, Ivory Tower didn't fail us...The game has around 40-130 cars (I couldn't find an exact number, these are the lowest and highest numbers of cars people told me about) , It has a huge variety of manufacturers going from Spyker to Lamborghini to Fiat ect.It's got all the cars we love, all the popular and even forgotten car manufactureres.You get "Specs" which are modifications for your vehicles, the specs are: Fullstock, Street , Dirt , Performance , Raid , Circuit. With DLC: Drift , Monster truck , Drag , Cops. STORY Nothing special, it's a racing game it doesn't require an in-depth story but we got one, without it the game would be a little odd but luckly we got one. You and your brother belong to the street racing network 5-10, it's illegal but popular, you and your bro go to meet the top dog, he kills your brother but you were accused of it as the cop leader was bribed with ALOT of money, you were sent to jail for about 5 years until you're partnered undercover with the cops, climbing the ladder to the top, going through leaders of spec vehicles , making them your friends until eventually, you're on the top with the killer, you confront him in a club, about to shoot him but you're smart enough not to, you do one last race with him, defeat him and he disappears, the cop leader gets jailed and you live happily ever after. OPEN WORLD The world is completely open, no invisible walls, nothing.You see a cliff in the playable area, you can go to it, the world is detailed and intresting , with sadly few easter eggs but fun ones, the world has some real race tracks and cities, the world is huge and it would take some time following 1 specific road from one end of the map to the other. GRAPHICS They're nice, especially in photo mode (check my profile for some screenshots), but they're pretty demanding, on my overclocked GTX 950 2gb vram I can run with SSAO+ , FXAA and mostly high settings at 60fps mostly at all times.Photo mode is beautiful, fell in love with it. PHYSICS They're weird, your car is stuck to the ground which is sadly annoying (can't go crazy with cliffs) but for overall driving feels good, you can play on "normal, sport , hardcore" modes which enable tc, disable tc ect.Drifting feels good, racing at high speeds does, collision is choppy but can deal with it.

FIVE times before you get into the gameplay they make it very apperent they want you buying wildrun DLC, this is stupid, was my 30 dollars not good enough?. 5 times I got advertisments shoved in my face before playing. not the point of a game.2. the camera snapping back uncontrollably to the forward position anytime W is pressed, now I understand why this is needed, GTA did a good job of this, smooth transitioning back to front view. the crew snaps you back when your trying to look left or right and it freaks out when you try to look anywhere but directly forward. This is a car game. I want to look at my car, and look where I want to go. not just straight. this was a game breaker for me 100%.3. after spending even more time tinkering with the steering controls, I for some strange reason couldnt tell I was driving a Camaro. I thought I was steering a bus. Game was unplayable for mydelf due to these very annoying features, dont get me wrong if these 3 things dont bother you, I hope you enjoy the game. Im just trying to save peoples time if they share my opinion.0.0/100

content:
ry 10, 2016
												8/10 - Fun, addictive game with lots of growth potential.  I gave it a 8/10 instead of a 10/10 because the game isn't easy to learn or it's not user friendly and it needs more cars; there are only a little more than 200 cars available in the game.  That said once you learn how to play, this game is amazing.  'The Crew' reminds me of my beloved racing game Gran Turismo, but much better and with traffic, an open world and random weather.  I played Gran Turismo 1-5, I'm familiar with the game and engine, this game is most definately built off the same platform.  The vehicle modifaction system has been changed and the game has a story with a plot as well as being massively multiplayer.  You're allowed to play all the game's different modes in a "Crew" or a 4 man team of your friends.  When you start out you have a choice of cars available at the Detroit car dealer.  As you unlock the game by beating story missions, there are 5 car dealerships and 1 motorcycle dealership.  I recomend starting with either the 2011 Mustang GT or the Nissan 370Z as they have several different specs the vehicles can be tuned to.  Much like Gran Turismo the vehicles are rated based on what 'The Crew' calls vehicle levels or Gran Turismo players know as performance points.  There are several different spec's a full stock car can be tuned to.  The game comes with 5 specs.  To unlock 'extreme specs' you need to purchase the 'Wild Run' upgrade.  Standard Specs:1 - Street2 - Dirt3 - Performance4 - Raid5 - CircuitWild Run 'Extreme' specs:A - Monster TruckB - DriftC - Dragand a new vehicle type: Motorcycles... which kick ♥♥♥ by the way.  Each spec a vehicle is tuned to can level up by unlocking parts via challenges, game missions or PVP events thus increasing it's performance point rating.  1299 is the max vehicle level/performance point rating available at this time.  As you complete missions new areas unlock, new vehicle specs and new vehicles are available.  The best way to earn money, rep and league points is to PVP.  It's by far the best way to earn money and rep.  You compete against other players based on how much you play, not how well you finish in races.  You have a choice of 5 PVP factions you can join.  The wolves, the snakes, the gators, the eagles, and some other faction that isn't memorable.  Your rep is compared to the rep of the other players in your faction.  If you have the highest rep in your faction, you're the boss and get a base salary of $150,000 per day.  If you're not the highest paid player, like most people, you fall somewhere in the middle.  Underboss = $100,000 daily, Street Boss = $60,000, Lieutenant = $30,000, Thug = $10,000.  I don't remember what Gangsta pays, but it isn't much, maybe $5,000 daily??  Yes finishing in 1st place pays better, but the difference between 1st and 8th isn't much.  The Devs encourage people to PVP with this system.  Traffic and collisions can be turned off to enhance your gaming experience.  Every player in the PVP lobby gets to choose what map they would like to race on.  Then based on what the players chose (5 players, 5 maps) the computer randomly selects one of the maps all of the players in the lobby chose and then everyone races on that map.  You can PVP solo or with a crew (4 man team).  To start I recomend the 2011 Mustang GT or the Nissan 370Z.  Both of these cars can be tuned to Street, Dirt, Raid, Performance or Circuit which is why I recomend them.  Money is tight early on in the game.  My recomended cars/bikes:Street: KTM 450, Nissan GTR, 2015 Mustang Fast BackDirt: KTM 450, RUF 3400K, HummerRaid: KTM 450, RUF 3400K, Buggy, HummerPerformance: Ford GT, Mclaren F1, Pagani Huayra, Lamborghini Superlegera, BMW 1000RR, Ferrari 458 SpecialCircuit: Ford GT, Lamborghini Superlegera, BMW 1000rr, Ferrari 458 Special

content:
er 16, 2014
												The Crew is one of those racing games that you just have to play even if it has Ubisoft's name on it. Let's get all of the BS rumors out of the way by saying UBISOFT DID NOT DEVELOP THIS GAME!!!! Ivory Tower developed this game with the ability of having 60 FPS at the start and yes it does have micro transactions but earning in-game cash is super easy. This game isn't tanted with Ubisoft's bad pc port mojo. This is a super stable game and I occasionaly experience a crash once or twice a day.So gameplay, how is it? Well the gameplay is well how any Need for Speed from Underground 2 through Carbon but with a twist. This game has RPG elements thats similar to Need for Speed World but is not purposly asking you to empty your wallets into a pay wall. It is open world and the world is really huge. It is close to 50 in-game miles and it will take you a long time to get you there. You have a level (50 is a max) in which you level up by doing story missions (yes it has a story), skill challenges, PvP events, and faction missions. The story missions is what it is labeled as, missions that's part of the story. The skill challenges offer a way to gain car parts (more on that later) and get some experience for doing it. There is also a leaderboard so you can compete against a person's ghost and see if you can get to the top of the leaderboard. PvP events are what it is labeled. You go against other players and you can choose to fight for your faction or just free-for-all. Faction missions are where you get a lot of money, faction experience in which that adds everyday you login, and some chunk of experience. They also have one hour long races and one that goes up to 4 hoursWhat are these car parts you mentioned above? Well those car parts give your car a level as well ranging from 0-1299. The car parts consist of a motorcore, air system, diff, tires, weight reduction, and more. There are five classes of cars and each car class is different to each other: There is Street, Dirt, Performance, Raid, and Circuit. Street is your step above stock. Dirt is something you would see from a World Rally Championship. Performance is your step above Street but is almost stripped out. Raid is something you see from the Dakar Rally and yes they have trophy trucks. Circuit is something you see from Grand Touring ot 24 Hour Le Mons racing. The car is completely stripped down with weight saving and high performance in mind with the ability to take corners.Well since this is a driving game, how are the physics? The physics can be odd but if you work around them, you can win a lot of the races. Drafting is a thing so use it when you can. The cars will tend to bounce off of things like bumper cars and it focuses a little on drifting.Hows the car customization? It is what you would expect from a Need for Speed Most Wanted and Carbon game. You can customize the interior with your choices of aluminum, carbon fiber, mixed aluminum, and mixed carbon fiber. You cannot place stickers anywhere you want to though. They have presets which look cool IMO.Car selection? How big is it? Well IMO it is small but it will slowly expand with DLC. The car list consists of 58 total cars but at least they have trucks.Final thoughts? Well I am enjoying the game. I am enjoying every bit of time I have put into the game. I would recommend everyone getting the Season Pass since they are going to add more cars. January 2015 is going to be their first DLC which should be an interesting one. I did wish they have given us the ability to move around the stickers rather than give us presets and working mirrors in the cockpit (yes a working cockpit). This game I believe will set a new standard on the illegal arcade street racing genre that was leaving a sour taste in my mouth because of the way Need for Speed has been going and from the look of things, it isnt going to get any better. You just have to play this game to know what I feel about this game. I have been dying to play a game thats open world with similar car customization as Need for Speed Most Wanted and Carbon but isn't trying to make your wallets screem and this is the answer my friends.UPDATE: Next Tuesday of updating this review, they are adding three more cars into the game if you don't count the Mini Cooper non-street edition we got at launch. I havent experienced any big crashes. Loading the game will freeze your computer if you are using a controller with XInput. I still would recommend this game. The AI can have some stupid rubber banding but AI can be difficult in a racing game.

I'd like it if I could pick my own exhaust, turbos, and other parts by brand and each having its own pros and cons in terms of how it effects your cars performance.I give it an 8/10.

content:
er 6, 2014
This game has taken EA's Need for Speed series out of the business once for all.For me, this could probably be the game of the year, from a considerable small choice list. THIS is how Need for Speed should have been for 10 years and counting (talking about NFSU and NFSU2 as best in the series, don't get me wrong). THIS is what modern racing games should aspire to. THIS is an example of a great "racing" game campaign (you don't get to play only racing missions, but also takedown, escape, time attack, contrabands and so on). THIS is an example of a good open-world game concept, as you're always busy with something, there's no such thing as boredom in this game, only if you're low on imagination. The bugs? They're pretty minor and unnoticeable at the moment of release. You can see a deer stuck in some fences, whatever. There's no game without bugs and here's nothing preventing you from playing.The graphics? They're good. I don't mind calling them great as they perfectly fit a strong 2014 game engine. There are enough graphics options, and also do not think that the game is locked to 30 FPS. We can also expect graphics mods in the future.The PC performance? Not bad, I must admit. The system requirements are pretty "fair", but whatever, even a low-mid spec laptop can beat this game on low settings. I didn't experience any sort of stuttering, FPS drops, all this kind of stuff.The handling? Feels good to me. You can say it's bad if you played any other good handling games, but you easily get used to the car handling. Might sound funny, but in cockpit view it feels even better to me.Buy the game and don't mind about the cons, you won't get disappointed.

content:
r 2, 2015
												I followed this game for quite a while before it came out. I was super psyched for a racing game with car customization in an open world, something Need for Speed has not done for a while now. However, I will admit that once it came out, I never really heard anything about it. It seems like I basically forgot. Then, a friend of mine got it and I ended up buying it on sale. Clearly, as you can see from my hours, I really have enjoyed this game. However, it has some serious quirks to it, and they aren't necessarily good. So, here's what I enjoyed about The Crew, and not so much.PROS:The Open World - I didn't realize just how big the map was until I really got into this game. It has, by far, the largest map out of any racing game I have played. I cannot compare it to FUEL simply because I have not played it, but it is bigger than every NFS game. And best of all? The map is not repetitive. You can drive from the swamps of the south to the deserts in the west, and have different scenery and small towns/cities in between. It mainly revolves around 5 major cities, and they are New York, Chicago, Miami, Las Vegas, and L.A. The developers certainly did their homework when it comes to the cities, and I applaud them for it. Even after 260 hours of gameplay, I still see places on the map I have not been, making the open world my favorite part of the game, by far.PvP - I find that the PvP is well done. You play in a lobby with up to 8 players at a time, who all choose exactly what event they want to do, and then the game randomly picks one of them. This includes events with any of the 5 specs. Some events are elimination, others regular races, and others a "king of the hill" type game. What's even better is the amount of in-game money you get from PvP. Even if you get last place, you still get nearly just as much money as the person in first, and this can make it enjoyable for anyone that plays. PvP is the best way to make money, currently. However, it still does matter what place you get, since there are PvP ranks in the game. The higher you place, the faster you rank up.The Graphics - Towards the end of 2015, a free update brought in new, updated graphics along with a weather system, which also includes slick roads after rain. This is all much better than before. Unfortunately, my lower-end GPU cannot handle max graphics, however, that is not to say that the game still looks very nice on High. It now looks more like a game released this year. Also props for it being a completely free update!Car Selection - You can have (almost) anything, from a LaFerrari, to a Hummer H1 Alpha, to a Dodge Challenger. What I like is that the game has 5 different specs for most cars (some ranging from just 1 spec to all 5), which are Street, Dirt, Performance, Raid, and Circuit. Take, for example, the Challenger. It can have all 5 specs, so if you want to go on dirt roads with one, you hop into the dirt spec Challenger. If you want complete offroading, you go with raid. And if you want to take it to the track or go extremely fast on highways, you get the circuit spec, and so on. What's nice is that you only buy one Challenger, and as you progress through the game, you get it in each spec, so you technically have 5 Challengers.NEUTRAL:The Police - I always enjoy it when there is law enforcement in an open-world racing game. At this point, I think it should be mandatory. The Crew, of course, has police, but they are only decent. Nothing more and nothing less. Unfortunately, this is where Need for Speed does something better than The Crew. During a police chase, even with 5 stars, there will never be any more than 5 police cars at once pursuing you, which by the way, are quite easy to take out. The roadblocks are laughable, since they never use anything other than the cars that are pursuing you to block the road, so you can usually speed right through them, unlike NFS: Most Wanted, which eventually has SWAT trucks that basically force you to take another route. There are also no spike strips. While it still can be fun to get into chases and have a friend taking out cops for you, I believe it could be made significantly harder at 5 stars with the use of bigger vehicles and spike strips.Customization - I'm very thankful that The Crew actually has customization to begin with, but it is really lacking. For one, you cannot choose from any color in the spectrum; you just pick from a preset list of colors. Second, the decals are mostly terrible. I tend to use the same 10-15 decals on most cars, or sometimes not at all, because most of the others are just bad looking and don't seem to fit any vehicle. Granted, that is personal preference, but for someone who has played NFS:Most Wanted and Underground 2, those are far superior in customizing.CONS:Uplay - I think you saw this coming. I know I did. Uplay is a requirement for The Crew, even if you buy it directly from Steam. You must download Uplay, and you must create an account. Although it can run in the background for the most part, the matter of the fact is that it is extra DRM that no one really wants, especially someone like me that only has 1 Ubisoft game. It also contributes to a longer startup time.The Story - Full of clichés and it being overall boring, the story is pretty much mandatory in order to reach level 50. The movie-like cutscenes in it are neat, but if you are like me, you'll do the story just to get it out of the way. The fun seems to come after it's over with.Smart Loot - This system is possibly the worst addition to The Crew since launch. Granted, before it was added, people still complained about the grinding system for leveling up your vehicle. Now, however, it is much, much worse. Instead of what used to be a much quicker, platinum only part grind where you could go up as much as +50 spec points in a single jump, is now down to as little as +1 for the same skills. Not to mention you also have a chance of winning a customization part, such as paint, or a bumper. This makes it very hard to get your car to 1299 (the max spec level), if you weren't a player before Smart Loot was added.Closing ThoughtsDespite some big flaws, I have enjoyed this game a lot, and I would say it's in my top 5 racing games now. The Crew, to me, earns an 8/10. If you can look past the cons listed above, I do recommend this game to any person that enjoys racing games, or is looking to try the genre in general.

number of helpful: 8 of 11 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
y 25
												I bought the game at launch, or a couple days after, here's my takeWHEEL USER'S REVIEW (Sim racer's point of view)The Crew does many things well:-Endless driving across the US-Decent feel through a T500RS (with the extraconfig.xml file you can find through ISR or Racedepartment)-Lenghty game overall-Though dated, looks nice-CarPG-Discoverables-Useable physics for low level cars (preferrably street or dirt specs primarily)However there's major things that this game does NOT do well:-Lateral grip loss (bad for drifting, though drifting isn't impossible)-HIgher level cars get more and more unrealistic, to the point where wheel users won't enjoy-Cops are....well, they don't matter, until they unrealistically and impossibly DO matter out of nowhere-The umpteen amounts of over-the-top "LOOK AT ME I AM STREET RACORZ" bling bling-Cut-scenes for every single action-New muffler part;  BRAKING BONUS!!!-Users without Calling All Units have major issues with constant annoyance to buy DLC, as well as friend disappearing when cops give chase, or simply alert that you have a slight bounty against them-Occasional drop-out of co-op missions-Honestly lame sound overallIt's a game I recommend to wheel users but ONLY if you're ok with using only half the content.  For wheel users specifically, once you get cars to a high enough level, or start using the higher specs of tuning, it becomes more and more arcade and unuseable for wheels.  It's not completely useless, but it definitely makes it more bland the more you progress.  The game's FFB (even with extraconfig.xml) strength is determined by vehicle weight, so the lighter the vehicle, the less FFB there is entirely.  Trucks and heavier vehicles naturally have more strength in the wheel overall.The FFB on the GOOD side, is pretty decent.  There's communication going on, and opposite lock (catching slides or drifting) is, in fact, there.  It's redeeming in itself, for a CARPG.On the BAD side, well, I've already mentioned the weight, but on Dirt, those forces nearly double overall.  It's rough on Dirt.  Some might complain due to lack of consistency, some might like it actually.  I kind of like it.The physics are....arcade, with a slight touch of realism.  At the lower levels, cars feel mostly natural.  On the higher levels, they float with total disregard for gravity and grip limits (HANDLING BONUS!!!).  Breaks are way too strong and acceleration is too fast.  The tires spin wildly, trying to impress somebody, yet nothing is happening on the driver's point of view.  Just generic wheel spin.  Still, there's a level of conservation needed to keep yourself from dying.  Snow is more fun to me.  I spent the entire game making sure I got as little HANDLING BONUS!!! BRAKING BONUS!!!....bonus's as possible.The sound is pretty lame.  Cars sound...well decently accurate, at least some.  They aren't terrible, but there's nothing to write home about.  Car engines are quiet overall, there's major leveling issues across the board and I don't play with music either.  Overall, it gets the job done, but don't expect to be wow'ed.  Some cars (namely Nissan Skyline R34) have pitch attenuation issues.Online portion is a dream come true....except for the fact that it's not.  Co-op is an awesome edition and cruising endlessly with friends is TRULY the meat of the game.  However, co-op doesn't mean anything, especially when you convince a friend to buy it so you can play together.  You already have all these tuned up cars that decimate the low level missions while your friend is feeling inadequate.  People disappear every time a cop chase is initiated, or you're alerted that cops are watching for you (or a friend).  Just left with a jittery name tag floating around.  It's annoying.  It works, it's not impressive, the concept is great, implemented rather poorly (but not so bad it's unplayable).  PVP matches are unbalanced, and for a wheel user, is not worth it honestly.  Once you max out your car's level through miscellaneous challenges, it becomes an arcadey mess, completely focused on top speed.Graphics are pretty nice.  There's nothing super amazing or perfect.  I'm running tripple screens and, though it doesn't support all the bells and whistles of simulators, it does have an FOV slider that works well.  I can't complain overall.  Looks pretty good, plays nice with peripherals it seems.Input device support:  I'm running a T500RS with a Basher boards FL2 adapter to run a G27 shifter on a seperate USB.  Works fine.  Took a minute to set it up.  Seems to be fine.  Like I said, I'm running tripples and it adds to the game greatly.  Though it won't quite run maxed with this setup smoothly.  980 4gb i5 3570 with 8GB RAM.Story:  I don't care.  I never will care.  You can't make me.  I've already gone through the NFS underground and beyond stories and I just plain don't care at all.  Well told I suppose, but flashy and stupid all the same.I recommend this game only because, as a wheel user with tripples and stuff, at the lower levels, this game is a great experience.  Endless driving exploration, co-op, driving with friends, just plain screwing around, drifting in Montana, some customization (though slightly limited in a way).  Stock, Street, Dirt, Raid and somewhat, Performance specs are fun to play with.  Beyond that wheel users won't have much fun with the floaty "super handling/braking" crap of the lighter cars.  It's fun having a 400hp Fiat 500, blasting away at RUF's and Zonda's like it's nothing.  The extraconfig.xml is absolutely necessary for good FFB overall.  It's hard to recommend otherwise, as there's obvious issues with the overall package, but still, it IS fun.  This is all outside the "review" of DLC and other things, which is complete BS overall.  I won't get into details, but DLC ruins some of the experience, unless you have money to throw away and get it all (then you won't have the game constantly pushing you to buy more things, as well as the online portion having less issues as a result).7/10:  Great concept, good open world exploration, bad end game, 50-50 for wheel users (dependant on vehicle class and level), horrible over-the-top-trying-to-impress-you fan service.

content:
26, 2016
												It's a bloody mess.I have to admit that I fell for the "we'll listen to the community feedback" lie, genuinely thinking that this game would go in the right direction.But it didn't. It went straight into a DLCfest.The season pass doesn't grant you access to all the paid content, Wildrun isn't part of it, and on top of that, it costs almost as much as the game itself.Plus, it gives so little content that it makes no sense to pay that much: a bunch of bikes, new specs made with recycled and/or slightly edited assets and a new gamemode which should be competitive, but in reality it's just about who glitches the most.The physics are broken, the cars don't feel alright at all. The steering capabilities also differ depending on input peripheral, with DirectInput ones having increased precision and steering radius, while keyboard and Xinput pads users get impaired controls. This issue hasn't been fixed, despite being a hot topic on the game's forums.Vehicles aren't many for today's standards and they're terribly unbalanced. While updates fix the handling of some cars, all they do is changing the current kings. On top of that, bikes seem to dominate in almost any spec and they're locked behind a paywall. Despite the major outcry on the forums for more balance, nothing seems to have changed yet. Moreover, the engine sounds are terrible.The only saving graces of this game are the graphics and the game world.

												Although i don't have as much playtime on this as some others, there is a lot to be said about the first impression of the game. Pros:Maps are richly detailed, i actually had to turn down settings so it wouldn't lag as much.Cars are nicely detailed, drivers side view allows you to look from side to side just like in real life.Good number of players aroundRacing is fun, although this has its own mechanics and an entirely arcade feel. It essentially feels like an early NFS title in how it handles. Think Underground 2 or Hot Pursuit 2.Cons: Glitchy! Sometimes you can ram a car hard, and the game will act like it was just a scratch, other times you will tap a car on the side lightly, and crash as if you rammed them. Speed of hit does not seem to matter.Microtransactions : YES, this does have microtransactions, although i do not see the need to buy cash unless you want to progress faster. It isn't quite as bad as i have seen in many games with a pay2win aspect. Not worth the base value. I waited for this to go on sale, do not buy this at full price. I don't think this is worth $60 let alone $85 for the Gold. Uplay: You must log in via Ubisoft's Uplay platform seperatly or make an account with them. Hackers and Griefers: Don't bother with the leaderboards.Handling: Normal racing mechanics do not seem to apply in this game. If you can get past the cons, there is some fun to be had in exploring and doing missions. Personally, i enjoy what i have played so far. Get it on sale.

												I highly reccomend this game just from playing the closed beta! It really feels like Test Drive Unlimited on steriods(which is good, because some of the original TDU devs worked on this game!). You get a good selection of radio channels, including a fantastic classical station, and a full interior view in beautiful detail. The world is obviously not a 1:1 scale of the US, but it is still immense, and you really can't get bored with this game from just driving around. Instead of TDU, where you just drive around Hawaii and look at pretty palm trees, this game has vast deserts, snowy mountains, and sprawling cities. I got to Las Vegas, and I was amazed by how much thought was put into the city's design. It is almost like the devs actually cared about making the game feel as good as possible. As of yet, I cannot speak of the car selection very much, but it seems like it shouldn't be too lousy. If you like open world games, or just want to see the good ol' USA, buy this now!

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2015
												The Crew has quickly become my favorite racing game ever. Let me first qualify by saying that I am not a racing sim fan but prefer arcade-style racers. Previous favorites have been Burnout: Paradise and Flatout: Ultimate Carnage. I also enjoy the DIRT and Forza series of games. With that said The Crew has an engaging story with a cinematic feel. I was able to play through the story at a casual pace in about 15 hours. The cut scenes are very well done and really draw you in. Once you finish the story there really isn't much that ties the campaign to the rest of the game however. I hope Ivory Tower (the developer) finds a way to create new missions which allow you to see what Alex and the 5-10s are doing instead of the player just running around the US doing races that don't connect with the story.Other than the disconnect from the story, once you make it to "V8" status then the open world really affords you many choices. In addition to the option to go back and re-race any of the campaign missions (to win better car parts) you can also run skill events. You must do wither of these to get better parts for your car(s) before you will have a chance in the PvP section. You can also race in Faction events which earn bucks that you can use to repurchase parts you have already won for cars you haven't yet upgraded or to buy entirely new cars.Speaking of cars, The Crew actually uses licensed cars from a wide variety of car makers including domestic and foriegn. Most of the cars are available to purchase with the bucks you earn in the game but others are only available if you pay real cash. The cost is relatively low and the season pass can make them even more affordable to buy all together. Each car has a variety of "spec" ratings from Full-stock, Street, Performance, Dirt, Raid and Circuit. Not all cars support all specs such as a Ferrari wouldn't have Dirt or Raid but many such as the Mustang GT have all so you can get really crazy with your builds. You can also customize the exterior and interior appearance of your rides and with the daily and monthly challenges you are encouraged to enhance your cars to earn more bucks. The variety of car looks and builds is pretty amazing. I rarely see the same configurations more than once when playing PvP.I could go on and on about this game but one of the things I like the most is that the developer, Ivory Tower, keeps enhancing and updating the game to make it better. Recently that added a league rating system and they routinely release new cars, tracks and events. The fact that this game continues to grow really makes it a great value. Unlike my past favorites I am always able to discover new things in this vast vehicular playground. Whether you buy The Crew on sale or at regular price you won't be dissappointed. This is one of the most fun and engaging racing games ever.Oh and did I say that there is a huge expansion coming in the fall: Monster Trucks, Motorcycles and Dragsters!!!!

												Ubisoft is even worse then EA. So, let me explain: The game itself cost 30 bucks, then you must pay 25 more dollars to get the DLC cars, AND THEN (yeah, thats not it) you must pay about 40 more "greens" to get another half of the game, with many new cars, game-changing specs of the cars, and many-many things. Great job Ubisoft!Now about the game itself. Yes its kinda good, but after you drove a little, completed the story mode, got EVERY car in the game in EVERY spec, drove the whole map, discovered tons of the bugs, like wall-breach and go-underwater bug, some skill races in top-50, you got basically nothing left to do.So the conclusion, should you buy it or not.Well, there is a litteraly a few people, like me, who can truly love it and fall into addiction, who think that the freeroam, huge map and 72 cars is enough (though i never felt like there is so much, and was actually shocked when i got that fact, as the cars feel pretty much similiar). If you want to risk, as its CAN be on of your favourite games, go ahead and buy "Trial" version for just 30 USD, and then decide if you ready to pay same to fall into that game for some hours more.

content:
y 25, 2015
												I've always been a fan of racing games. Doesn't matter what type or style it entailed. The Crew has its good and its bad. Lets go with the bad first.The only real negatives I can personally give is once you hit level 50 and can get Platinum level cart parts it's a straight crap shoot at getting a level 50 car part. This is my biggest complaint. It's purely random, meaning you might get it on the first try or not get it for fifty tries or more. Also on the car parts that you "unlock", which allows you to buy the car part on another car instead of having to Story/Skills missions for the same part is restricted to which car spec you use when you unlocked that car part so if you get it through a Street spec car you can only buy it on a Street spec car, Any other car spec you will have to unlock seperately.The car assists are split into three types, all assist, sport, and hardcore. None of which can be changed for what you want or don't want when driving. This is mildly annoying, but it also knows if you're using a controller or a steering wheel. Avoid using a keyboard if all possible with this game.The NPC cars in Faction missions and the Police are cheaters, to put it as nice as possible, since it doesn't matter what surface they're driving on they will never lose any traction. The Police are lacking in the sense of you can drive by them at ridiculous speeds and run red lights/stop signs and they do not attempt to chase you. The only way to get a police chase is to either run into them or cause enough collateral damage during a Police Watch to trigger them into chasing you. Maybe this can be patched later to make them more like actual cops.The car selection is nice, it isn't on Gran Turismo or Forza level, but it's sufficient. Overall the customization isn't bad either. Visual car aestetics are fairly wide until you get to Raid and Circuit specs (Since they are only color, sticker, tag, and rims options.) Again it isn't at the level of being able to make your own designs and putting them on your car. (I know why, mostly in the sense of people making poorly designed gentailia...) There are enough stickers and color variety to not run into same design, unless everyone in your session is obsessed with The Fast & the Furious.The achievements can be entertaining in their title and down right fun to do depending on the prerequistes.This game isn't for the simulator type player, it plays more to your Test Drive, Need for Speed and Burnout types. Even the adventerer in you will find it fun to be able to drive across the United States finding known landmarks throughout. The story isn't anything new, but it was still fun to watch and have some sort of cinematics and build some level of character developement for the people you add to your crew over the course of your exploits.Oh, make sure you have some friends too, this is far more fun with people you know than driving it alone. At the end of the opening credits it says, "Never Drive Alone" and for good reason. Despite the flaws in this game I still see more posistive than negative, but what do I know since I'm the same guy that's been playing APB/APB:R for 3+ years. :)

												I beta tested the game on the PC 2ed beta  for a few hours and it has improved from that. I have just finished getting to level 50 (max) and played through the whole story.The problems with this game are:You have to be connected to the server to playReally??? Is their a time when you wont have the internet and still be able to run this game because most laptops will not run this game and the data rates are low enough.Extreme rubber banding AIThe AI can be pretty easily fixed because it was already fine in the beta so all they have to do is find a balance between the beta and the official game  AI.server issues Well it is only day 2 now so you can expect to see improvements soonMISSING VEHICLES AND SPECS THAT WERE IN THE BETA!I don't even know?! How can you have more cars and specs for them and not put in your official launch game when they were in the BETA! THIS BETTER NOT BE A PLOY TO GET MORE DLC INTO THE GAME! I am hopeful that their were issues with them and they will be adding them in the game (FOR FREE) when the time comes.  Maybe handling issues!?!I say this because I don't think players understand how these vehicles work. Full stock= Slidey Street= Not as slidey and fasterDirt = Slower made for trails/driftyPerformance= Gripey 2ed fastest highway/streetRaid= trucks that raid any where and are slowestCircuit= Grip mobile fastest highway/flat roads with some twistsYou see alot of people only had access to level 10 in the beta witch is only the top 3 specs and they were saying it was like "driving on ice" Each car handles different in the different spec and each spec has their own general handling so their is a lot of leeway in how the cars handle, not to mention the small upgrades for the vehicles in game that affect handling. Having played lots of racing games (simulator/arcade) it is defntly more toward the arcade side but it does have a wide range of different types oF driving. These are the most persistent and worst issues of the game but all of it can be fixed through patches and updates, only time will tell if they will attempt to fix these issues.The good?Map beautiful and  huge with fast travel to anywhere you have been NEAR !A good selection of vehicles just not a huge spectrum (needs companies like DMC, Tesla, Hennessy and a few others that are part of American history (THE GAME IS ABOUT AMERICA more American cars please!) ) All kinds of exploring4 player/ multi-player Free content updatesCurrently 48 vehicles with different specs for each (HOPEFUL MORE WITH UPDATES AND NOT DLC AS THEIR IS ALREADY TO MUCH DLC)This game works well with wheels (Has used the logitech driving force gt (was $120 new) for the whole playthrough but I recomend the logitech g27 if you can afford it $200)etc. Those of you that this is more of a money issue i would just wait untill its on sale but if you like mixed racers want to explore with friends or new people and have the pc to run this game well, get it. I enjoy the game for what it is worth and I hope that if you do buy it you enjoy it as well.  $ 85 (game+dlc) is a lot for a title I just hope my purchase and hopes were not misplaced.oh and uplay still sucks and it always will!  (you need it to run the game)

												I do like this game but there are still way to many things to fix. Cop AI isn't very bright, but when they are driving on your sides, you're screwed. There is no way out of that the cop cruisers refuse to move, not like a car would act normally.Also the difficulty for some missions is so artificial its angering. Most of the time, your car level needs to be well over the recomemded level because there are always 1-2 cars that just fly ahead of you and stay ahead of you. Also i noticed when a friend of a much higher level helps a much lower, the opposing racers are on par with the high level friend. Wait what?! At this point the lower level is better off on his own. The opposing AI car levels still have a low number but match speed with the high level pretty much throughout the whole race.I know the big map is great and all, but its not 20 miles from Miami to Chicago. At least make it more reasonable.Amidst all this backlash, I still recomend this game. For those who play it like a game not like something of a speed run. Which is what about half of the other people are complaining about.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2014
												The Crew is the 2014 textbook definition of polarizing, even before it released. On the one hand, it is an open-world racing game, giving you the opportunity to drive from one end of the United States to the other. On the other hand, Ubisoft.This polarization extends in-game as well. One minute, I could be screaming at the screen because I failed a raid mission for the fifteenth time: My car had forgotten how it was supposed to work and a tiny rock about two pixels in size sent it careening sideways into fifteen trees like the world's worst lumberjack. The next, I would be driving through the snowy Rockies with the sun shining on my face as I drifted through a corner, pondering whether it was possible to operate the steering wheel with my massive erection.It's a beautiful game with an adequate roster of cars (58 cars including Season Pass, possibly more to come) and wonky physics and I've loved every second of it.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 13, 2014
												So after Eurogamer.net gave it a 8/10, I decided to give the game ago with a buddy of mine. Holy crap I did not expact to have this much fun.  First things first, the game is an arcade racer. Don't expect anything along the lines of Gran Turismo et al. The game handles like ye'olde typical arcade game. Honestly, that is a good thing. I have Asetto Corsa to fill the enthusiast needs. It has been quite a while since I've enjode an arcade racer. Actually, the last time I remember having this much fun was with "Ultim@te Race".  I am only a few hourse in, so here is why I like the game in a nutshell:1. Pretty/adequate graphics. 2. Runs like butter. Fast 60fps no stutters,,,,nuttin. Considering how bad Unity and Watch Dogs was I am pleasantly surprised. 3. Huge game world , which means while you do the typical race activities, the tracks are diverse and fresh.4. The coop is fun. Just plain fun. 5. The RPG like mechanics keep you going in a "just on more upgrade" kinda way. It is fun to see all those players driving around you all the time. Makes the world feel alive. This game is certainly not for everyone, but if you, like me, just want to play an arcade racer with your buddies.....then give it a try....at least when it is on sale.  So far I am not regretting paying full price though.That being said, I did loose connection with the servers once every hour. Which is a minor annoyance.

ry 27
												Overall it's quite a decent driving game, good fun. Except that collision boxes on NPC vehicles are rather broken...And that the NPCs have to be the stupidest drivers ever, they don't exactly move out of the way (I think theyre fixed on rails until something hits them)...And that you lose connection to the servers a lot...And that there's a bug where you can't see people in your crew when their nametag is right next to you...And that an NPC police car can go faster than a McLaren 12C doing 250mph...But its made by Ubisoft so what did you expect? Oh and also it's a complete rip off on Steam (psst use an external site, you can get it for 6quid *wink*)But to be perfectly honest if you don't mind a few problems here and there it's a decent driving game. Having full customisation on your vehicles is brilliant, earning money is pretty easy, and actually has a pretty decent story line.Graphically it's brilliant, full max settings at 1080p (16x AA etc.) on a gtx1060 6GB it never drops below 60FPS.Gonna give it a 7.5/10, the good parts outweigh the bad, would recommend.

r 16, 2016
												Haven't beaten the game yet, but so far I really enjoy it. Since I upgraded my CPU to an i5 4690, I no longer stutter and lag which makes it extremely enjoyable. The world is beautiful, the cars are beautiful, the mechanics are, ok, arcade-y or not realistic, but that's ok. If I wanted to play a simulator I'd do that. I really like the huge world aspect, it makes the game much more interesting to explore and drive around on. Only complaints I have are the confusing methods to upgrade and decorate your car. It took me hours to figure out how to simply change the paint on my car, and where to go to get upgrades or visual changes. I also wish I could get much cooler cars sooner, like Ferrari's, Lambo's, etc. For now I'm still stuck with the Nissan for 10 hours, whereas in NFS Rivals I could afford a top of the line car by 10 hours. Anyway, pretty fun game, and I'll probably get the Calling All Units DLC this November!

content:
5, 2015
												I don't usually write reviews, but Ubisoft announced a large expansion for this at e3 today and I want to see them continue that kind of support. My initinal impression: 7/10My current thoughts: 9/10My cousin and I preordered this game and started playing it as soon as it was released. I'll be honest, it's not what I expected at all. I was hoping for another Test Drive Unlimited, so for the first while playing it I didn't like it much. We ended up stopping for three months before picking it up again and now it is one of my favorite games. They've made a lot of changes and fixed a lot of things, but I also like the game for what it is now, not what I wanted it to be. I've spent hours just driving aimlessly to see what I can find, more than half the time I'm not even on a road, I'm using a RAID spec vehicle (think offroad racing truck type of vehicle) to drive where there aren't even roads because the team even put detail into those parts of the map.Speaking of Specs, that's what makes this game so cool. Currently, I am using a 1969 Camaro for all races. I have a version that is basically an offroad buggy meant for driving where there aren't roads, another that is a high-performance circuit racer, a street racing version, a dirt track version, and a NFS-type high-performance street race version. The same car becomes 5 VASTLY different cars, each handling differently and meant for different types of races and terrains. You simply can't drive a Circuit car in a RAID race, that'd be like driving a formula one car in a rally, it just doesn't work. The same is true vice versa. But you can use the same car as both specs if you want.The story mode is pointless, I won't disagree with that, but this game is meant to be an MMO, the story doesn't really matter. It's only there to introduce you to the different specs for PVP events. It is still fun with a crew of course, but pretty boring by yourself. My cousin and I never even finished it. We got as far as unlocking the last SPEC and then focused on PVP events and faction events. PVP events and faction events are what's the most fun. They are races of all types across the US. My favorite race is a RAID race going down the side of a snowy mountain, it's high speed and there are no roads. Faction events can vary in length between less than 10 minutes to over an hour. That seems crazy at first but with a crew it is fun. The entire map is covered with challenges like speed, escape, jump, raceline, etc. to get upgrades for your car like loot drops in an MMO. It's a great way to keep just driving interesting as well. But most of the time you will probably avoid them if you're just driving because really, this game makes just driving feel great.I'm looking forward to what is planned to be added to this game, they said they will support it for a long time and I really hope so. This is the kind of game you can drive for hours without even doing anything and still enjoy yourself, whether or not there is even a road in visible distance of you.

0, 2015
												If you are a fan of cars and racing games definitely pick this up. The handling seems a little arcadey and needs to be adjusted a bit in the settings and of course like all racing games a controller is always nice. But honestly the game will give you hours of fun upgrading your favorite cars, testing you skills in pvp or on solo/crew missions, and roaming around a toned down map of the USA. (with multiple race tracks to find might i add). The only possible downsides is that upgrading the cars can feeling like endless grinding to get the part you want, BUT it really isn't bad, also that the cop chases are pretty sub-par and lastly you need uplay.Closing note about the negative reviews:Most seem to be about the difficulty of the game and how some missions might need multiple people. Honestly all I have to say about the difficulty is git gud :p I had no problem with the game at all (not to mention a little challenge is always fun!)  and in terms of the missions that may need multiple people, there is an option before the mission inviting all people that you can see to help you, so finding multiple people is easy!Please do not let the negative reviews put you off from this game and remember to read them carefully!

content:
2, 2015
												The Crew. A game that I'd followed for a fair few months before its BETA release, and then jumped off the train to "buyingit-ville" very shortly before release. For another 8 months I fondled with the idea of buying it, but never did. I didn't really know why... until now.Now, before I start, I should clarify that no, I didn't "thumbs it up" by mistake. I bought this game on sale for £12 and I feel it's worth that. But a penny more? No.An open world, multi-purpose racing game with vast amounts of custimization that is also an MMO. Sounds great, right? Let me further clarify those for you.Open World...and then some. Oh boy, the map's huge! I always thought GTA V's map was big, but this must be at least 4x the size of Los Santos. Not only is it big, based around the entirety of the USA and time-consuming to travel across, but it's also incredibly detailed. The sale price was worth it for the gametime on that map alone. Even without missions, it would still be enjoyable for me. You might want to get a plane if you're going from NY to LA though.Multi Purpose Racing/CustomizationYou betcha! Dirt, Raid, Perf(ormance), Street and Circuit specs will make sure that you definitely have the right tool for the job (or the race, in this case)! The car detailing with these specs is very nice. Cars look crisp, although some more than others, for some reason, and there's a lot to do in the customization front (bumpers, fenders etc.).The A.I. however is a joke. It would seem that Ubisoft believe that you should have to hard brake around track corners in a specially circuit-tuned race car that should turn on a dime, only to fall off track and lose your first place position to the guy in last 1 mile back. But, the guy behind you in a Chevy V8, with tyres the size of a standard London road-lane and the turning circle of a cruise ship? Oh, no trouble there! In fact, they don't have to even brake! Their car has high-performance, rubberised glue... apparently. Oh, and if you can actually manage to pull off a first place medal against the sling-shotting A.I., don't expect it to be gold. You're going to need a harrier jet for that. Available in the new DLC , which you'll be able to grab in your nearest showroom for the low, low price of £25.M.M.OHa! Yeah right. I haven't played W.O.W in a few years, but unless their servers have changed to allowing a whopping 8 players in one match(!), then it is an insult to even put this into the same category.ConclusionIt's a fun game. Has a lot of bugs but a lot of them are rarely noticable. It's a great time-waster and the cars look good, especially when you put a big ol' body kit on 'em. Buy it, but don't pay full price for it, even if that is only £25. Also, be prepared for a ton of in-game currency being thrown in your face. Seriously, it's like hitting a wasps nest with a baseball bat; overwhelming and really, really stupid.

												I expected better of you, Ubisoft. I'm going to have to give a thumbs down for this game, and I doubt you'll ever see another penny coming out of me for your incompetence for a horrendous buisness practice (in-game cash shop after buying an AAA title game) and trying to force everyone to use your bad game launcher (UPLAY)I bought the game being hyped when everyone saw the amazing CGI Cinematic Trailer The Crew showed off when it was first released on youtube, everyone really thought we were gonna have fun, join together as one with a Crew, with those being huge in the car culture, the trailer really represented us gamers what we really wanted and expected out of The Crew, to no avail tho the game itself was not like the trailer... sadly.The Game was okay at the time, bought the gold edition that included seasons pass and had unlocked most of the sweet cars, seemed like a sweet deal. Despite the fact that the CGI Trailer was no where near close to how the game itself really was, The Crew was overall a game that had more pro's than cons at the time of it's releaseUbisoft then decided to be money hungry, and not only did they change the way how end game worked by reducing the chances of farming rare parts through skills (pushing for people to buy in-game currency and or pvp for them (again low chance), and ADDED a DLC which was not INCLUDED IN A SEASON'S PASS (which I also bought) and the DLC didn't contribute to anything that The Crew was at first, it didn't even make me want to come back to the game, all they did was add a competitive content that had barely ANY interactions between players, a bunch of monster trucks and motocycles that had basically nothing to do with the game as well. Drifting was a nice addition and was probably the only good thing out of the DLC, Drag racing was somewhat of a pointless feature in the game.All in all with current status of this game.The Crew is now in my opinion one of the worst car racing MMOs to date with the recent updates. I have to say.. Good job Ubisoft you finally surpassed EA in being the worst publisher and game developer ever existed in the gaming industry, it's like you ACTUALLY WANTED recognition for it and ♥♥♥♥ people off with your half made games that aren't even complete, even your game launcher is WORSE than Origin. JUST HOW can you not learn from your mistakes?Again, not one penny out of me until I see things improve with you guys.
